GLOBAL.IN_PROGRESS: ⚠ This website is currently being developed, and work is in-progress. Some links may be dead.

HOME.BODY_INTRO: Hello, I'm Nishant Suria. I make games as N.S. Dawn.
HOME.BODY_INTERESTS: Outside of game design, I am interested in linguistics, multilingualism and second language pedagogy, world cultures and cuisines, and digital art. With my work, I seek to connect human conversation with play, and to demonstrate the power of language.

LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/PROJECTS_1_TITLE: a phonetic investigation of tamil liquids
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/PROJECTS_1_DESC: Standard Tamil is said to have five /ɾ/, /r/, /l/, /ɭ/ and the elusive /ɻ/. Using phonetic data elicited from native speakers of Tamil, Fourier analysis was used to determine an auditory basis for this five-way distinction.
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/PROJECTS_2_TITLE: a phonological framework for japanese vowel devoicing using OT
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/PROJECTS_2_DESC: In Japanese, vowels can get devoiced, such as in words like つき /tsuki/ → [tsɯ̥ki]. While the triggers for vowel devoicing are easily explained, interactions between environments, pitch accents, and knockout conditions make the full extent of the phenomenon hard to explain without Optimality Theory.
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/PROJECTS_3_DESC: A small script that facilitates the lookup and comparison of features used in phonological analysis. Originally made for UCSC's LING 101.
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/FEATURE_LOOKUP/DESC: feature_lookup.js is a program that facilitates the lookup and analysis of phonemes and features used for phonolgical analysis. Originally made for UCSC's LING 101.
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/JAPANESE_VOWELS/DESC: The following is the full paper. Description coming soon.
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/GAME_OF_TONES/DESC: This is a project for UCSC's WLMA, which works on Mesoamerican langauges. Description coming soon.
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/TAMIL_LIQUIDS/TITLE: a phonetic investigation of the retroflex approximant in Tamil
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/TAMIL_LIQUIDS/DESC:
For my Phonetics seminar in Winter 2023, under Grant McGuire, I decided to investigate the relatively unique sound /ɻ/, as it is present in Tamil. Specifically, I sought to answer the following questions.

(I) To what degree of audible distinction /ɻ/ produced by Native Tamil speakers? This sound is said to be being lost in Urban Tamil dialects, merging with /ɭ/.

(II) What acoustic signals may listeners be using to distinguish between /ɻ/ from other liquids? For English, the third formant (F3) is used to distinguish /ɹ/ from /l/, lower F3 being strongly correlated with rhoticity. Does this correlation hold for languages with a richer liquid inventory?

Analyzing the articulations of seven speakers, I was able to assemble a pilot analysis. View full paper > (somewhat outdated)
LINGUISTICS.LINGUISTICS/TAMIL_LIQUIDS/DESC_2: I was invited to present my findings at the Linguistics Undergratuate Research Conference (LURC) at UCSC, for which I fortified my analysis and used the k-means clustering statistical method to justify my conclusion. I prepared the poster presentation seen above (click to view.).

RESUME.TITLE: curriculum vitæ
RESUME.OPENER_DESC: I am an introspective game designer and language enthusiast, interested in multilingual and cross-cultural design. I have experience in several game engines and strive to maintain a varied skillset. I always endeavor a lot with a little, and uphold a high level of sincerity in my work.
RESUME.EMPLOYMENT_1_DESC:
↘ Via recommendation from professor, worked as the appointed group tutor for multiple Linguistics classes.
↘ Worked with professors and TAs to organize multiple sessions every week to provide support to students.
RESUME.EMPLOYMENT_2_DESC: ↘ Worked under Rachel Walker, professor in Linguistics at UCSC to edit, analyze and interpret phonetic data collected from Ladin, a minority Romance language spoken in Northern Italy.
RESUME.EDUCATION_1: BA | Arts, Games, and Playable Media

ABYSS.PLATFORM_1_DESC_1: // welcome to platform ①, the footstep of the abyss.
ABYSS.PLATFORM_1_DESC_2: // the abyss is a place where half-baked and tiny projects, buck-wild ideas and superfluous scrawlings end up. like this thing.
ABYSS.PLATFORM_1_DESC_3: // i'll keep updating this place with content when i feel like it. no organization, just a sprawling mess, loosely connected with links. very web 1.0 vibe.

ABYSS.PLATFORM_1/GIT_DESC_3: // next, you're going to need to do the following. this will create a new orphan who will work to fix any issues.
ABYSS.PLATFORM_1/GIT_DESC_4: // we'll go ahead and add an empty file called f.txt. the f stands for 'fix'.
ABYSS.PLATFORM_1/GIT_DESC_5: // now, to commit these changes, we start by adding the files.
ABYSS.PLATFORM_1/GIT_DESC_7: // finally, here's the important part. go ahead and copy the following into the command line. if you're using 'main' as your main branch name, use the second one.
ABYSS.PLATFORM_1/GIT_DESC_8: // and there you have it, all your problems are solved!
ABYSS.PLATFORM_1/GIT_DESC_9: // right after you're done with that, in order to fix the problems that still exist locally, you can fix them recursively using the following command.
